docs.lead_paragraph: When President Clinton presents his $1.64 trillion budget for 1997 on Tuesday, it will be the opening initiative in a new phase of the Presidential race in which Pennsylvania Avenue supersedes the hustings. An unprecedented contest between a President of one party and the sitting Senate majority leader of another is now under way, and advisers to both Mr. Clinton and Senator Bob Dole say the campaign will be waged in the next few months in a legislative battle over a few issues. Central among them are the balanced budget, with its ancillary issues of Medicare and Medicaid, and welfare and other health care proposals.

headline.main: A Campaign Calculator for the Budget

docs.lead_paragraph: The State Senate Appropriations Committee yesterday voted to extend unemployment benefits from 26 weeks to 32 1/2 weeks to win support from labor leaders for a plan to solve the impasse on the financing of hospital care for uninsured New Jerseyans. The bill would allow the state to continue tapping into the unemployment insurance fund for so-called charity care for the next two years, but would cut financing from its 1995 level of $400 million to $275 million. Since the most recent charity-care financing plan expired on Dec. 31, the state has missed two $33 million payments to repay hospitals for treating the uninsured.

docs.lead_paragraph: After wrapping up his latest primary victories last week, Senator Bob Dole said it was "time to go back to work" in Washington. Coming from a man who has been fighting hard in the campaign all year, that comment spoke volumes about the unfinished business facing the Republican Congress and President Clinton. The latest word is that Mr. Dole will push for perhaps dozens of ideologically driven bills on the budget, tax cuts, welfare reform and other issues, forcing the President to wield his veto pen. Both Mr. Dole and Mr. Clinton may be thinking that more confrontation will enhance their credentials as effective leaders. Naive as it sounds, we think voters would prefer results to further posturing.

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN Joan Borgatti's doctor told her that he wanted to do a bone marrow transplant to treat her breast cancer, she thought she was going to die. After he explained the procedure to her, it made sense: who was a better candidate for the latest cancer treatment than a 30-year-old mother of two? Bone marrow transplants have traditionally been used as a last resort in treating cancer patients at university-based teaching hospitals. With the development of infection-fighting drugs like nupogen, the risks have been significantly reduced, making it a more common procedure. The Hudson Valley Bone Marrow Transplant Center at St. Joseph's Hospital in Yonkers opened in 1994 and is one of about a dozen small community-based hospitals in the United States that are using the procedure to treat aggressive cancers.

headline.main: In Yonkers, the Cancer Fight Broadens

docs.lead_paragraph: SO much goes unsaid when Bob Dole calls for a balanced budget and less regulation to get the economy booming again. Or when Bill Clinton offers his formula of more public spending on job training and education to bring back the old prosperity. As the chief rivals for the Presidency, they are engaging in a rather traditional campaign debate -- one that assumes the American economy can go back to the high growth of another era. That is what goes unsaid. The candidates challenge each other with conflicting nostrums for generating growth. Push the right policy buttons, they say, and presto, the economy will boom. What they don't debate is whether strong growth -- the sort that would raise living standards and make layoffs less frequent -- is in fact possible.

headline.main: Trickle Down;It's a Slow-Growth Economy, Stupid

docs.lead_paragraph: AS the curtain falls on act one of the 1996 Presidential election, a question naturally arises: How did an angry, change-hungry electorate, whipsawed by broad economic forces and mistrustful of the very idea of a political establishment, end up with two utterly conventional career politicians as their parties' nominees? Maybe, as Patrick J. Buchanan argues, it is because the shadowy insiders and special interests in Washington have thwarted the voters' hunger for fundamental change. Maybe the party establishments have won a short-term, tactical victory but only by tamping down those volatile political forces that will come back to haunt them this fall.

headline.main: In This Race, It's the Center Against the Middle

docs.lead_paragraph: TO most of its employees, the Gannett Company makes no excuses for economizing on health care. Those who want to pick their own doctors and hospitals instead of sticking with the cut-rate Communicare Choice network, a company brochure warns, face high deductibles, low payments and, potentially, thousands of dollars of added expense. All for a good cause, Gannett vouches. Communicare Choice, the brochure says, "addresses the dilemma facing most businesses today -- how to continue to provide good health-care coverage and keep costs in check."

headline.main: A Double Standard In Health Coverage

docs.lead_paragraph: For the Canadiens, tonight's game was the first at Molson Center, which has replaced the Forum. For the Rangers, it was the debut of three new players, all veterans, obtained in a trade. So there were automatic excuses for the ragged quality of play in Montreal's 4-2 victory. The first would be the ceremonies, which delayed the face-off by almost 30 minutes and may have inspired the home team.

headline.main: Rangers Give Canadiens A Housewarming Gift
